Health & Safety for Licensed Child Care Providers, Module C
Section 3: Emergency Preparedness, Response, & Recovery

Go vs. Don't Go

Letâ€™s elaborate on our methods for establishing barriers from the threat. The method used to remove children and staff from a threat is dependent on the threat.

Please hover or tab over the cards below to find out more about when to go or don't go.

Shelter-in-Place

A shelter-in-place is used for situations when staying inside the building is the safest action. A shelter-in-place is used with a tornado. A shelter area should be selected that is an interior windowless room on the lowest level. Avoid places with wide-span roofs like gyms. This also might be the recommended approach from First Responders in various other emergencies.

Lockdown

A Lockdown is used in a situation such as an intruder. The building should be secured with the lights out, and the doors locked with furniture up against them. In the case of a missing child, you should lockdown, call 911 and the parents, and assign staff to search for the child. Child care providers should stay in lockdown until a first responder dismisses them.

Evacuate

You would evacuate a building for situations like a fire, flood, or gas leak. Make sure you have posted exit signs, and established meeting locations and an evacuation plan that accounts for everyone.

Relocation

Relocation is used if you are not able to stay in or near the building. You should have 3 temporary shelters identified in your plan; one in the neighborhood, one out of the neighborhood, and one out-of-town. Make sure you have transportation worked out for if you need to relocate.

LARA Rules for Family and Group Homes (R400.1945) and Centers (R400.8161) state that child care programs must include a plan for each of these methods in their written emergency plan.
